ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
Know that pride [kibr] is among the destroyers, and no one among creation is free from some measure of it. Its removal is an individual obligation [fard 'ayn], and it is not removed by mere wishing, but rather by treatment and employing the remedies that suppress it. In its treatment are two stations: the first is the eradication of its root from its origin and the uprooting of its tree from its planting place in the heart [qalb]. The first station is in eradicating its root, and its treatment is both intellectual ['ilmi] and practical ['amali], and healing is not complete except by their combination. As for the intellectual: it is that he knows himself and knows his Lord, the Exalted, and that suffices him in removing pride [kibr]. For whenever he knows himself with true knowledge [ma'rifa], he knows that he is more abased than every abased one and less than every insignificant one, and that nothing befits him except humility [tawadu'] and abasement and lowliness. And when he knows his Lord, he knows that grandeur ['azama] and majesty [kibriya'] are not fitting except for Allah. As for his knowing himself, it is also lengthy, but we mention from it what is beneficial in arousing humility [tawadu'] and abasement. It suffices him to know the meaning of a single verse in the Book of Allah, for the Qur'an is the knowledge ['ilm] of the first and the last for one whose insight [basira] has been opened. And He, the Exalted, has said: "Destroyed is man [insan]; how ungrateful he is! From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfa] He created him and proportioned him. Then He made the way [sabil] easy for him. Then He causes him to die and puts him in a grave. Then when He wills, He will resurrect him." Indeed, the verse points to the first creation of man [insan]: he was not a thing mentioned, and he was in the realm of non-existence for agesâ€”indeed, his non-existence had no beginning. And what thing is more vile and less than obliteration and non-existence? He was like that in pre-eternity. Then Allah created him from the vilest of things, then from the filthiest of them, for He created him from dust [turab], then from a sperm-drop [nutfa], then from a clinging clot ['alaqa], then from a lump of flesh [mudgha], then He made him bones, then He clothed the bones with flesh. This was the beginning of his existence when he became a thing mentioned. He did not become a thing mentioned except while being upon the vilest of descriptions and attributes! For he was not created complete at his beginning; rather, He created him an inanimate, dead thingâ€”he did not hear, nor see, nor feel, nor move, nor speak, nor grasp, nor perceive, nor know. He began with his death before his life, and with his weakness before his strength, and with his ignorance before his knowledge ['ilm], and with his blindness before his sight, and with his deafness before his hearing, and with his muteness before his speech, and with his misguidance before his guidance, and with his poverty before his wealth, and with his incapacity before his power. This is the meaning of His saying: "From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfa], a mixture [amshaj]." And the meaning of His saying: "Has there come upon man [insan] a period of time when he was not a thing mentioned? Indeed, We created man [insan] from a sperm-drop [nutfa], a mixture [amshaj], to test him." Likewise, He created him first, then bestowed favor upon him, saying: "Then He made the way [sabil] easy for him." And this points to what was made easy for him during the period of his life until death. And likewise He said: "From a sperm-drop [nutfa], a mixture [amshaj], to test him; so We made him hearing and seeing. Indeed, We guided him to the way [sabil], whether he be grateful or ungrateful." Its meaning is that He gave him life after he was an inanimate, dead thingâ€”dust [turab] first, then a sperm-drop [nutfa]. And He gave him hearing after he was deaf, and gave him sight after he was lacking vision, and strengthened him after weakness, and gave him knowledge ['ilm] after ignorance, and created for him the limbs with what is in them of wonders and signs after their absence, and enriched him after poverty, and satisfied him after hunger, and clothed him after nakedness, and guided him after misguidance. So look how He managed him and formed him, and to the way [sabil] how He made it easy, and to the transgression of man [insan] how ungrateful he is, and to the ignorance of man [insan] how He made it manifest? ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
Know that arrogance [kibr] is among the destructive traits, and no one among creation is free from some measure of it. Its removal is an individual obligation [fard 'ayn], and it is not removed by mere wishing, but rather by treatment and employing the remedies that suppress it. In its treatment are two stations: the first is the eradication of its root from its origin and the uprooting of its tree from its planting place in the heart [qalb]. The second is repelling its incidental manifestations through the causes by which a person becomes arrogant over others. The first station is in eradicating its root, and its treatment is both intellectual ['ilmi] and practical ['amali], and the cure is not complete except by their combination. As for the intellectual: it is that he knows his own soul [nafs] and knows his Lord, the Exalted, and that suffices him in removing arrogance [kibr]. For whenever he knows his own soul [nafs] with true knowledge [ma'rifa], he knows that he is more abased than every abased one and less than every insignificant one, and that nothing befits him except humility [tawadu'] and abasement and lowliness. And when he knows his Lord, he knows that grandeur ['azama] and majesty [kibriya'] are not fitting except for Allah. As for his knowledge [ma'rifa] of his Lord and His grandeur and His glory, speech on that is lengthy, and it is the ultimate knowledge [ma'rifa] of unveiling [mukashafa]. As for his knowledge [ma'rifa] of his own soul [nafs], it is also lengthy, but we mention from it what is beneficial in arousing humility [tawadu'] and abasement. It suffices him to know the meaning of a single verse in the Book of Allah, for the Qur'an is the knowledge ['ilm] of the former and the later peoples for whom his insight [basira] has been opened. And He, the Exalted, has said: "Cursed is man; how disbelieving he is! From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfa] He created him and proportioned him. Then He made the way easy for him. Then He causes him to die and puts him in a grave. Then when He wills, He will resurrect him." (80:17-22) Indeed, the verse has pointed to the first creation of man: he was not a thing mentioned, and he was in the realm of non-existence for agesâ€”indeed, his non-existence had no beginning. And what thing is more vile and less than obliteration and non-existence? He was like that in pre-eternity. Then Allah created him from the vilest of things, then from the filthiest of them, for He created him from dust, then from a sperm-drop [nutfa], then from a clinging clot ['alaqa], then from a lump of flesh [mudgha], then He made him bones, then He clothed the bones with flesh. This was the beginning of his existence, when he became a thing mentioned. He did not become a thing mentioned except while being upon the vilest of descriptions and attributes! For he was not created in his beginning complete; rather, He created him as a lifeless, inanimate object [jamad]â€”he did not hear, nor see, nor feel, nor move, nor speak, nor grasp, nor perceive, nor know. He began with his death before his life, and with his weakness before his strength, and with his ignorance before his knowledge ['ilm], and with his blindness before his sight, and with his deafness before his hearing, and with his muteness before his speech, and with his misguidance before his guidance, and with his poverty before his wealth, and with his incapacity before his power. This is the meaning of His saying: "From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfa] mixed?" (80:18-19) and the meaning of His saying: "Has there come upon man a period of time when he was not a thing mentioned? Indeed, We created man from a sperm-drop [nutfa] mixed that We may try him." (76:1-2) Likewise, He created him first, then bestowed favor upon him, saying: "Then He made the way easy for him." (80:20) And this is a reference to what was made easy for him during the period of his life until death. And likewise He said: "From a sperm-drop [nutfa] mixed, We try him, so We made him hearing and seeing. Indeed, We guided him to the way, be he grateful or be he ungrateful." (76:2-3) And its meaning is that He gave him life after he was a lifeless, inanimate object [jamad], dead, dust first and a sperm-drop [nutfa] second. And He gave him hearing after he was deaf, and gave him sight after he was lacking vision, and strengthened him after weakness, and gave him knowledge ['ilm] after ignorance, and created for him the limbs with their wonders and signs after their absence, and enriched him after poverty, and satiated him after hunger, and clothed him after nakedness, and guided him after misguidance. So look how He managed him and formed him, and to the way how He made it easy for him, and to the transgression of man, how disbelieving he is, and to the ignorance of man, how He has made it manifest? So He said: "Does man not consider that We created him from a sperm-drop [nutfa] and at once he is a clear adversary? And of His signs is that He created you from dust; then, at once, you are human beings dispersing." (36:77, 20) So look...

And as for its end and destination, it is death, indicated by the saying of the Exalted: "Then He causes him to die and buries him, then when He wills, He resurrects him." And its meaning is that He strips him of his Spirit (Ruh), his hearing, his sight, his knowledge, his power, his sensation, his perception, and his movement, so he returns to being inanimate matter as he was the first time. Nothing remains except the form of his limbs and his image, with no sensation in it nor movement. Then he is placed in the earth and becomes a stinking, filthy corpse, just as he was in the beginning a despised drop of fluid. Then his limbs decay, his parts disintegrate, his bones become hollow, and he becomes scattered remains and fragments. And the worms eat his parts, beginning with his pupils, plucking them out, and his cheeks, cutting them off, and with all his other parts, until he becomes dung in the bellies of the worms and becomes a corpse from which animals flee and which every human finds repulsive and flees from due to the intensity of the stench. And the best of his states is that he returns to what he was and becomes earth from which cups are made and from which buildings are constructed, so he becomes non-existent after having been existent. And it is as if he had not been reaped yesterday, just as he was in his first state a long duration. And would that he remained thus, how excellent it would be if he were left as earth. No, rather He revives him after a long decay to experience severe torment. He emerges from his grave after the gathering of his scattered parts, and he emerges to the terrors of the Resurrection, and he sees a standing Resurrection and a sky split and torn, and an earth changed, and mountains set in motion, and stars falling, and a sun eclipsed, and dark conditions, and harsh, severe angels, and Hellfire blazing, and a Paradise which the criminal looks upon and regrets, and he sees the records.

Indeed, water and soil alone are not sufficient. For if the seed were left in damp, solid, compacted earth, it would not sprout due to the absence of air [al-hawa']. Thus, it requires being placed in loose, friable earth into which the air can penetrate. Yet the air does not move to it by itself; it requires a wind [rih] to move the air and drive it with force and violence against the earth so that it penetrates it. To this, the saying of the Almighty alludes: **"And We send the fertilizing winds"** [Qur'an 15:22]. Their fertilization [ilaqah] lies in effecting the coupling [al-izdiwaj] between the air, the water, and the earth. Then, all of that would not suffice you if it were in extreme cold and harsh winter. Thus, you need the heat of spring and summer. So it has become clear that its nourishment depends on these four elements. Now look at what each one requires. The water needs to flow to the farmland from the seas, springs, rivers, and canals. So look how Allah created the seas, made the springs gush forth, and caused rivers to flow from them. Then, the land may be elevated, and the waters do not rise to it. So look how Allah, the Exalted, created the clouds and how He subjected the winds to them to drive them, by His command, to the regions of the earthâ€”they are heavy clouds, bearers of water. Then look how He sends it down as abundant rain upon the lands in the time of spring and autumn, according to need. And look how He created the mountains as reservoirs for the waters, from which springs gush forth gradually. Had they emerged all at once, the lands would have been flooded, and the crops and livestock would have perished. The blessings of Allah in the mountains, the clouds, the seas, and the rains cannot be enumerated. As for the heat, it does not arise between the water and the earth, for both are cold. So look how He subjected the sun and how He created it, despite its distance from the earth, to heat the earth at one time and not another, so that cold occurs when cold is needed and heat when heat is needed. This is one of the wisdoms of the sun, and its wisdoms are too numerous to count. Then, when the plant rises from the earth, the fruits require firmness and solidity to form, so they are in need of a moisture to ripen them. So look how He created the moon and made from its specific property moisture [al-tartib], just as He made from the specific property of the sun heating [al-taskhin]. It ripens the fruits and colors them by the decree of the Creator, the All-Wise. For this reason, if trees were in a shade that prevented the rising of the sun, the moon, and the other stars upon them, they would be corrupt and deficient. Indeed, a small tree becomes corrupt if a large tree shades it. And you can know the moistening effect of the moon by exposing your head to it at night; moisture, expressed as a cold [al-zukam], will overcome your head. Just as it moistens your head, it also moistens the fruit. We shall not prolong discussion of what cannot be fully comprehended. Rather, we say: Every celestial body [kawkab] in the sky has been subjected for a type of benefit, just as the sun was subjected for heating and the moon for moistening. Not one of them is devoid of many wisdoms which human strength cannot enumerate. Were it not so, their creation would be futile and vain, and the saying of the Almighty would not be valid: **"Our Lord, You have not created this in vain"** [Qur'an 3:191], and His saying, the Mighty and Majestic: **"We did not create the heavens and the earth and that between them in play"** [Qur'an 21:16]. And just as there is no limb in your body except for a benefit, there is no limb in the body of the world except for a benefit. The entire world is like a single person, and its individual bodies are like limbs for it, cooperating just as the limbs of your body cooperate within your whole body. Elaborating on this would be lengthy. You must not think that believing the stars, the sun, and the moon are subjected by the command of Allah, glorified be He, in matters made as causes [asbab] for them by the decree of Wisdom, contradicts the Sacred Law due to what is reported therein of the prohibition against believing the astrologers and against the science of the stars. Rather, what is prohibited regarding the stars is two matters: The first is that you believe they are independent agents [fa'ilah] of their effects, acting independently, and that they are not subjected under the management of a Manager who created and overpowered them. This is disbelief [kufr]. The second is believing the astrologers in the details of what they inform about of effects which are not commonly perceived by all of creation, for they say that out of ignorance. Indeed, the knowledge of the decrees of the stars was a miracle for some of the Prophets, peace be upon them. Then that knowledge was effaced, and nothing remained except what is mixed, wherein truth cannot be distinguished from error. Therefore, believing the celestial bodies [al-kawakib] to be causes [asbab] for effects that occur by the creation of Allah, the Exalted, on the earth, in plants, and in animals, is not detrimental to the religion [din]; rather, it is truth. But claiming knowledge of those effects in detail while being ignorant is detrimental to the religion. For this reason, if you have a garment you have washed and wish to dry it, and someone says to you, "Take out the garment and spread it, for the sun has risen and the heat of the day is intense, and the air is still," you are not obliged to disbelieve him, nor are you obliged to deny him by attributing the heat of the air to the rising of the sun. And if you ask about a change in a person's face and he says, "The sun struck me on the road, so my face darkened," you are not obliged to disbelieve him in that. Judge all other effects by this standard, except that some effects are known and some are unknown. It is not permissible to claim knowledge of the unknown. As for the known, some of it is known to all people, like the occurrence of light and heat with the rising of the sun, and some of it is known to some people, like the occurrence of a cold [al-zukam] with the rising of the moon. Therefore, the celestial bodies were not created in vain. Rather, within them are many wisdoms that cannot be counted.

Indeed, let the human [insan] reflect upon his food [ta'am]. We poured down water [ma'] in abundance, then We split the earth [ard] open, splitting, and caused to grow within it grain [habb], and vines [â€˜inab], and fresh herbage [qadb], and olive trees [zaytun], and date-palms [nakhil]. Then the plant, when it rises from the earth, finds in the fruits a hardening and firmness, so it needs a moisture to ripen them. So look how He created the moon [qamar] and made from its specific property moistening, just as He made from the specific property of the sun [shams] heating. So it ripens the fruits and colors them by the decree of the Creator, the Wise [al-Fatir al-Hakim]. And for that reason, if the trees were in a shade preventing the rising of the sun and the moon and the rest of the stars upon them, they would be corrupt and deficientâ€”to the point that a small tree is corrupted if a large tree shades it, and it is known... So We say: Just as wood and soil do not nourish you, but rather you need a specific food, likewise the seed does not nourish itself with everything, but rather it needs a specific thing. The proof is that if you left it in a house, it would not increase because nothing surrounds it except air [hawa'], and mere air is not suitable for its nourishment. And if you left it in water, it would not increase. And if you left it in an earth containing no water, it would not increase. Rather, it must be in an earth containing water, so that its water mixes with the earth and becomes mud. And to this is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: "Let the human reflect upon his food. We poured down water in abundance, then We split the earth open, splitting, and caused to grow within it grain, and vines, and fresh herbage, and olive trees, and date-palms" â€” the verse. Then water and soil are not sufficient, for if you left it in a moist, solid, compacted earth, it would not sprout due to the absence of air. So it needs to be left in a loose, porous earth into which the air penetrates. Then the air does not move to it by itself, so it needs a wind [rih] that moves the air and strikes it with compulsion and violence upon the earth until it penetrates into it. And to this is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: "And We sent the winds as pollinators" [15:22]. And their pollination is only in effecting the coupling [izdiwaj] between the air and the water and the earth. Then all of that is of no avail to you if it is in extreme cold and harsh winter, so you need the heat of spring and summer. Thus, the need of its nourishment for these four has become clear. So look at what each one needs. For the water needs to flow to the land of cultivation from the seas, springs, rivers, and streams. So look how Allah created the seas and made the springs gush forth and caused rivers to flow from them. Then the earth may be elevated, and the waters do not rise to it. So look how Allah, the Exalted, created the clouds and how He subjected the winds to them to drive them by His permission to the regions of the earthâ€”and they are heavy clouds, carriers of water. Then look how He sends it down pouring upon the lands in the time of spring and autumn according to the need. And look how He created the mountains as preservers of the waters, from which the springs gush forth gradually. If they came out all at once, the lands would be flooded and the crops and livestock would perish. And the blessings of Allah in the mountains, the clouds, the seas, and the rains cannot be enumerated. As for the heat, it is not obtained between the water and the earth, for both of them are cold. So look how He subjugated the sun and how He created it, despite its distance from the earth, to heat the earth at one time and not another, so that cold occurs when there is need for cold, and heat when there is need for heat. This is one of the wisdoms of the sun, and the wisdoms in it are more than can be enumerated.

And we do not elaborate on mentioning the instruments of the plant in attracting nourishment to itself, but we point to its nourishment. So we say: Just as wood and soil do not nourish you, rather you need specific food, likewise the grain does not nourish itself with everything, rather it needs something specific, as evidence that if you leave it in the house, it does not increase because nothing surrounds it except air, and mere air is not suitable for its nourishment; and if you leave it in water, it does not increase; and if you leave it in land with no water in it, it does not increase. Rather, it must be in land with water that mixes its water with the land, becoming mud. And to this is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: 'Then let man look at his food: We poured down water in abundance, then We split the earth in fissures, and caused to grow therein grain, and grapes and fresh vegetation, and olives and date-palms' (Quran 80:24-29). Then water and soil are not sufficient, for if it is left in damp, solid, compacted land, it does not sprout due to lack of air, so it needs to be placed in loose, porous land where air penetrates to it. Then air does not move to it by itself, so it needs a wind that moves the air and strikes it with force and violence upon the land until it penetrates into it. And to this is the allusion in His saying, the Exalted: 'And We send the winds fertilizing' (Quran 15:22). And its fertilization is in effecting the coupling between air, water, and land. Then all of that does not benefit you if it is in excessive cold and harsh winter, so you need the heat of spring and summer. Thus, the need of its nourishment for these four has become clear. So look at what each one needs: water needs to flow to the land of cultivation from seas, springs, rivers, and canals. So look how Allah created the seas, gushed forth the springs, and made rivers flow from them. Then the land may be elevated, and waters do not rise to it, so look how Allah, the Exalted, created the clouds and how He subjected the winds to them to drive them by His permission to the regions of the earth, and they are heavy clouds bearing water.
